citeinfo.origin: Rocky Mountain National Park GIS Program
citeinfo.title: Lakes of Rocky Mountain National Park

pubinfo.publish: Rocky Mountain National Park GIS Program

descript.abstract:
These data depict the hydrography (water) resources of Rocky Mountain National Park. It is derived and developed from a number of sources. These include:
> 1:24000-scale USGS Digital Line Graph (DLG) data, > 1:24000-scale USFS Cartographic Feature File (CFF) data, > GPS (Global Positioning System) data.
These data have also been updated and upgraded using heads-up digitizing using USGS DOQ's and color DOQ's developed for Rocky Mountain National Park as a backdrop.
**NOTE** - These data are available as either an ESRI coverage, or as separate ESRI shapefiles, and this one metadata file is valid for all those data.
When in COVERAGE format, both arc and polygon data are in the one dataset. Due to the limitations of the ESRI shapefile format, this hydrography data is contained in two separate shapefiles: Lakes.shp (polygons) and Streams.shp (vectors).
These data were originally compiled in 1995, and have been incrementally updated and upgraded as needed.
These data depict only vector and polygon features (streams, lakes, etc.). Point hydrography features (wells, springs, diversions, etc.) are located in other datasets of the Rocky Mountain National Park GIS database.
These data cover a 39 quad area centered on Rocky Mountain National Park. The 7.5 minute USGS quads covered are:
Clark Peak, Chambers Lake, Comanche Peak, Pingree Park, Crystal Mountain, Mount Richthofen, Fall River Pass, Trail Ridge, Estes Park, Glen Haven, Bowen Mountain, Grand Lake, McHenrys Peak, Longs Peak, Panorama Peak, Trail Mountain, Shadow Mountain, Isolation Peak, Allens Park, Raymond, Granby, Strawberry Lake, Monarch Lake, Ward, Gold Hill, Rawah Lakes, Boston Peak, Kinikinik, Rustic, Big Narrows, Poudre Park, Buckhorn Mountain, Drake, Pinewood Lake, Lyons, Boulder, Laporte, Horsetooth Reservoir, and Masonville.
descript.purpose: Data used and/or developed by the Rocky Mountain National Park GIS Program is used in the protection and management of Rocky Mountain National Park.

idinfo.useconst: Not for use at scales greater than 1:24000

cntperp.cntorg: Rocky Mountain National Park GIS Program

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.2.2.1350

attracc.attraccr: The attribute accuracy is deductively estimated to be "good". If a higher proof of data accuracy is required, do not use these data. User is advised to FULLY and CAREFULLY READ the "DISTRIBUTION LIABILITY" section of this metadata before using this data.

dataqual.complete: Data is considered complete. Some datasets are parkwide in scope, while others were developed and/or updated to address specific management concerns within particular spatial coordinates. Users of this data are advised to FULLY and CAREFULLY READ the "DISTRIBUTION LIABILITY" section of this metadata before using this data.

horizpa.horizpar: Horizontal accuracy varies depending on the source of individual components within the data. Data derived from USGS data (DLGs, DEMs, DOQQs) are assumed to meet National Map Accuracy standards, though extensive experience in using USGS data for the Rocky Mountain National Park area has shown that many data components have spatial errors exceeding the National Map Accuracy standards. Data produced from GPS (Global Positioning System) field data is assumed to be spatially accurate to within 2-5 meters.

procstep.procdesc:
The park acquired 17 1:24000-scale USGS DLG datafiles covering 17 7.5 minute quads of Rocky Mountain National Park. This is the only 1:24000-scale USGS DLG data available for this area (Aug 1998). The USGS quads covered by this DLG data are: Clark Peak, Chambers Lake, Comanche Peak, Pingree Park, Mount Richthofen, Fall River Pass, Trail Ridge, Estes Park, Glen Haven, Bowen Mountain, Grand Lake, McHenrys Peak, Panorama Peak, Trail Mountain, Shadow Mountain, Isolation Peak, and Allens Park. This data was used as the primary basis for this coverage.
The data was received in DLG-3 optional format and was imported into the data base using the ARC/INFO DLGARC command. The line attributes in the resulting "<cover>.ACODE" file were moved to the <cover>.AAT file using the ARC/INFO command JOINITEM. Similarly, the polygon attributes in the "<cover>.PCODE" file were moved to the <cover>.PAT file using the ARC/INFO command JOINITEM.
Cartographic Feature Files were used to fill in and extend this coverage in and around Rocky Mountain National Park. The 22 USGS 7.5 minute quads covered by this CFF data are: Boulder, Gold Hill, Ward, Monarch Lake, Strawberry Lake, Granby, Lyons, Raymond, Pinewood Lake, Longs Peak, Masonville, Drake, Horsetooth Reservoir, Buckhorn Mountain, Crystal Mountain, Laporte, Poudre Park, Big Narrows, Rustic, Kinikinik, Boston Peak, and Rawah Lakes.
"A Cartographic Feature File (CFF) is a digital data file containing a vector representation of the point and line features shown on a Forest Service Primary Base Series (PBS) map. CFF data are collected by digitizing PBS maps and revised using correction guide information provided by field units. The feature categories contained in the CFF are: transportation (roads and trails), streams and water bodies, political and administrative boundaries, land ownership, and other cultural features. Elevation contours, vegetation, and text (geographic names, labels, etc.) are not included in the CFF."
The USFS CFF data was in ARC/INFO export format and was retrieved from the Colorado Rockies Regional Cooperative (CORRC) server. CORRC has since ceased to exist.
The USFS CFF data was imported into 22 separate coverages using the ARC/INFO command IMPORT. These coverages were then combined into one coverage using the ARC/INFO command APPEND. No polygon attributes were present in the CFF data. Attributes were added to vectors and polygons using the ARC/INFO ARCEDIT module and ARC/INFO TABLES commands. Items of CFF origin in the <cover>.AAT file were altered to match those created and added to the DLG derived coverage. The DLG and CFF derived coverages were joined together using the ARC/INFO command APPEND.
Additional vectors were added, and some 1:24000-scale vectors were replaced with more accurate vectors created by collecting GPS data. Line data were collected using Trimble GPS (Global Positioning System) equipment. All data was post-processed with Trimble's software resulting in an accuracy of 2-5 meters. Line features were edited and splined to clean up vectors using the ARC/INFO ARCEDIT module. Line features were edited and snapped to create polygons using the ARC/INFO ARCEDIT module. Attributes were added to vectors and polygons using the ARC/INFO ARCEDIT module and ARC/INFO TABLES commands, though some attributes were attached to the data in the field using a pre-defined data dictionary. See <URL:http://www.trimble.com> for additional information regarding the specifications of Trimble equipment. Presently (July 1998) Rocky Mountain National Park is using a Trimble Pathfinder Professional and Trimble GeoExplorer IIs to collect GPS data.
Additionally, some vectors were added and others adjusted using heads-up digitizing technique (digitizing off of the computer screen) using 1:12000-scale USGS DOQQs as a backdrop.
Additionally, some vectors were added and others adjusted using heads-up digitizing technique using color DOQQ's developed from September 2001 aerial photography as a backdrop.
Additionally, attributes were added to vectors and polygons using the ARC/INFO ARCEDIT module and ARC/INFO TABLES commands, though some attributes were attached to the data in the field using a pre-defined data dictionary when GPS data was collected. MAJOR and MINOR attributes were derived from the text description supplied by the CFF item "CFF_WORD", and the final text field DESCRIPTION was populated with the MINOR1 code description as defined in the USGS "Digital Line Graphs From 1:24,000-Scale Maps--Data Users Guide 1".
Additionally, the NAME text field was populated with the official USGS place name for each feature as identified on paper 1:24000-scale 7.5 minute USGS quads. The SOURCE item and SYMBOL item were also populated at this time.

overview.eaover:
If this dataset if a COVERAGE: the first four items in the polygon attribute table (PAT), or the first seven items in the arc attribute table (AAT) are automatically generated by ARC/INFO software. Contact ESRI (Environmental Systems Research Institute, Inc.) or read their literature for detailed descriptions of their internal file structure. ESRI can be reached at <URL:http://www.esri.com.>
If this dataset is a SHAPEFILE, the first two items in the data table are automatically generated. Contact ESRI or read their literature for detailed descriptions of their internal file structure. ESRI can be reached at <URL:http://www.esri.com.>
These attributes are common for both the VECTOR and POLYGON data:
The MAJ0R1 item is the USGS DLG major1 attribute code.
The MINOR1 item is the USGS DLG minor1 attribute code.
The MAJ0R2 item is the USGS DLG major2 attribute code.
The MINOR2 item is the USGS DLG minor2 attribute code.
For more information and examples of attribute codes, see the following USGS publication: "Digital Line Graphs From 1:24,000-Scale Maps--Data Users Guide 1".
The SYMBOL item is populated by a number that represents either a polygon fill or a line symbol. Used exclusively in cartographic production in ArcInfo ArcPlot.
The DESCRIPTION item is a text field that describes the feature in plain text. Descriptions can be a single word or a simple phrase.
The NAME item is a text field populated by the official USGS place name of the feature.
The SOURCE item defines the source of individual components within the data set. Values may include:
> DOQQ/USGS - arcs, polygons, and/or points derived from features visible on > 1:12000 USGS digital orthophotoquads > DOQQ/2001 - arcs, polygons, and/or points derived from features visible on > ROMO's color digital orthophotoquads > 1:24K DLG - components originally from 1:24000 USGS digital line graph >data > GPS - arcs, polygons, and/or points collected with Global Positioning > System equipment
Other values might exist.
The NOTE item contains any additional pertinent information in text format. Additional information can be a single word or a simple phrase.
The FISH item is a alphanumeric code that relates to a fish inventory database compiled by the USFWS for RMNP. Those data are not included with this dataset.
This attribute only applies to the POLYGON data:
The ACRES item is a numeric field populated by multiplying the AREA item by 0.0002471054, or by use of the NPS AlaskaPak for ArcGIS extension.
This attribute only applies to the VECTOR data:
The MILES item is populated by multiplying the LENGTH item by 3.280839895, or by use of the NPS AlaskaPak for ArcGIS extension.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

distinfo.distliab:
The National Park Service shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein. These data and related graphics (if available) are not legal documents and are not intended to be used as such. The information contained in these data is dynamic and may change over time. The data are not better than the original sources from which they were derived. It is the responsibility of the data user to use the data appropriately and consistant within the limitations of geospatial data in general and these data in particular. Any related graphics (if available) are intended to aid the data user in acquiring relevant data; it is not appropriate to use related graphics as data.
The National Park Service gives no warranty, expressed or implied, as to the accuracy, reliability, or completeness of these data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from an NPS server and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the National Park Service, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the utility of the data on another system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data.
